Transcription for 1814211

I have been asked to record my experiences, my wartime experiences of World War II.
Who am I? My name is Dennis Tidswell. I live in Pembroke.
I'm now 98 and a half years old, and unfortunately that wonderful human faculty of memory does begin to fade.
So before it goes completely, I will make every endeavor to talk about those experiences, something that I hadn't done before.
I think to appreciate my feelings during the wartime, and my experiences, it would help a little to go back to my childhood days to know what you're dealing with.
I was brought up in a small village called Gindros, which is about three and a half miles outside of Swansea.
My father was a member of the Swansea Police Force.
He, during the First World War, was in the Grenadier Guards and rose through the ranks and at the end of that war was granted a commission.
Now he always told me that in the forces, if you wanted a commission, you needed a private income, which was something I didn't have when I came to the point of becoming a member of the forces.
During my young days, society in Forrest Falk and indeed the whole of Wales was passing through a very deeply religious fervor.
There were indeed two fractions of society. There were the deeply religious and then there were the otherwise non-believers who had a very different kind of life.
But my life was church three times on a Sunday and the whole area was literally covered in Welsh chapels with names like Calvaryan, Bethany, Zion, Sarum, Teroselam, Hebrum.
Then there was one established church, which I think was called the Church of Hysard in those days. Church in Wales hadn't appeared on the scene.
And then there were the other denominations of the Gospel Hall, the Baptists, the Homeward Witnesses, Salvation Army and the Congregational.
And it was to the Congregational Church that I was sent three times every Sunday.
So here we had this young lad brought up very strictly in a very religious atmosphere.
I vivid recollections of being taken to the largest Welsh chapel called Calvaryan in nearby Forrest Falk.
I stood I suppose about almost three feet tall at several inches of age amongst a congregation of probably, let's say 400 or more people,
giving full voice to the bread of heaven, which literally lifted the roof and to me was almost a terrifying experience.
There was tremendous noise. However, that's just an aside.
The other factions of society of course were the pub goers and the billiard halls and the club goers.
Welsh soup was dry in those days. There were no drinks on a Sunday in pubs, but you could get a drink in a club.
But there were two very distinct factions of society.
So I can't say I had a particularly good education.
I wasn't able to take the eleven plus. I had as a young man a labors facial tick, which set me back a bit in that my parents took me everywhere to try and cure this.
I have distinct memories of being taken to someone called a phrenologist who made an analysis of what may be wrong with you by the bumps in your head.
Anyway, by the time I had come round to about 14 years of age, that tick unfortunately disappeared.
My interests mainly were swimming, cycling, tennis and amateur dramatics.
When the war broke out in 1939, I soon found myself somewhat on my own because a lot of my friends who were slightly older had joined the forces in one way or another.
I was now an insurance clerk with a company called the London Shores.
I had made up for my poor education by evening studies and getting various certificates for mathematics and accountancy, and I was studying insurance examinations.
My favorite hobbies were photography and radio.
My father was a keen radio amateur and in the early 30s we were just coming out of the crystal set and moving into wireless sets made with thermionic valves.
So he had taught me how to build a wireless set.
So one day I took it into my head that I would like to join the Royal Air Force.
Another one of my hobbies was aerial modeling and flying model airplanes.
So one particular morning I would go to the RAF recruiting office at the bottom of Page Street in Swansea and sat in front of this group of these RAF officers.
I said, what age are you my boy? I'm 17. Come back when you're 18.
As I passed the sergeant at the entrance way, he said, you're 18 next week, aren't you boy?
I said, no, no, it's next July. You're 18 next week, aren't you boy?
So I got the message and I kept...
Two or three weeks later I found myself sitting in front of this group of RAF officers at the recruitment center.
They go into your educational background and then ask about your past times and hobbies.
When I mentioned that I was interested in wireless and could build a wireless set, they cottoned onto that one and talked very much about that.
I wanted to train very much as a pilot.
That was the whole object in joining the Air Force, to learn to fly and to be a pilot.
But they said that why wouldn't I join now as a radio operator?
And then at some later date I could quite easily remaster and train as a pilot.
But things didn't quite turn out that way.
A radio operator had nothing to do with flying at all, I discovered.
It was really very high frequency intercommunication between ground and aircraft.
So it was all different to what I intended, but I went along with that.
And in a matter of a couple of months really I was called up.
Apparently they were very short of radio operators at that particular time.
So here we had this somewhat naive young man leaving home for the very first time to go out into the big wide world.
My mother cried, my father said, I'll make a man out of him.
And off I went and started at Uxbridge, which was a recruiting centre.
And then on to Padgate, in terms of language.
I seldom have ever heard the F word. That was certainly not part of the vocabulary.
In July 1940 I turned up at the recruiting centre at Uxbridge amongst quite a few others, hundreds of people.
We were put into groups of about 50 and we were sworn in.
And here you agree to obey orders and keep to the King's regulations.
So no one had ever read them. And of course an allegiance to the sovereign.
And once you had sworn those orders you were no longer a civilian, you were now a member of HM forces.
And indeed this was a defining moment which put you firmly in your place.
I was now an Aircraftman, second class.
And we were then directed to some tents which were on grassland between some rather nice looking brick buildings.
But they were not to be our sleeping place. We were shown where we were to sleep.
And that was in a tent on a straw palliats which was damp and musty and smelly.
With one blanket and a sausage, a canvas bag, I suppose about 9 inches in diameter.
And that was your pillow and that was where you were to sleep. Henceforth you were to wash and shave in cold water.
Now this indeed was a second part of the culture shock. However that was only to last about 4 or 5 days.
And we were then put into a billet as it was called, which was like a Nissan hut with cast iron pipes.
Fortunately it was July so there was a reasonable temperature.
And it contained a number of steel bed frames with the wire springs across. And three were called biscuits.
And they were the mattresses you slept on divided into three sections.
And two blankets, rather coarse things, made you scratch your niche. And the sausage as a pillow.
And that was your sleeping quarter.
There was a corporal's room at the end and the corporal was invariably a regular airman.
And the chairman sort of shat because he would wake you up in the morning very politely.
Come on here sods, wakey, wakey, get your hands out your cocks and get moving and stand by your beds at 8 o'clock.
Very friendly sort of, you know, got a greeting.
Anyway, when you stood by your beds you were taught how to stand to attention for the only officer who came out, looked you up and down from bed to bed.
And I felt this business of being stood to attention not very much to my liking.
And you were usually commanded to stand to attention in the presence of an officer.
And the command of stand to attention is being like placed in an invisible straitjacket with your arms bound to your sides and your legs immobilized and your brain literally numbed by the aura of class distinction.
I found this was an ultimate humiliation and I felt degradation.
Now they put you in your place and at their mercy more move or twit an eyebrow at your peril.
However, there was no going back.
I had sworn allegiance to a sovereign, one I had never met or ever likely to, yet under whom I was prepared to sacrifice the one life I had.
So it behoved me now, I felt, to accept my surroundings and I volunteered for it, so just get on with it.
And I think that was the right move because otherwise life could have been very miserable indeed.
Anyway, at Uxbridge you then came to being kitted out.
Kitted out. You're saying farewell to your civilian clothes and you're now about to don a uniform.
In this great big hall, loads of tables and piles of clothes, you woke up to the counter, height five foot two, and could fly at you a tunic.
Before that you'd been given a white kit bag. It stood about three foot high, a little bit of foot in diameter, and for the time being you simply put all this uniform into this kit bag.
So it came flying at you at the rate of knots. Length of inside length? 27. Okay.
All this clothing, shirt, dress, pants came hurling at you and then the one final thing, a pair of boots.
I never wore boots in my life, but I was about to learn what it was like because at Uxbridge you were taken out on to the parade ground by the drill sergeant, who was another very polite gentleman.
I won't repeat a lot of the way he described us, but anyway, marching back up and down, the boots were chuffing my ankles, and red wool legs around my ankles.
You were given a rifle now. What did the rifle have to do with the RAF? I don't know, but of course you had to learn the appropriate drill.
So we were given a Lee-Enfield rifle, no bullets, and all the cleaning kit and the gear, and trained how to use it in marching and on parade.
When I turned came to do a guard duty at night, you present yourself with a guard room, and they tell you you take your sentry post at the station entrance, and obviously you challenge any on-comer who goes on.
So I said, well, where are the bullets? They said, give me those bullets. So you were guarded in the place, but you didn't have any bullets, but now all that stage passed, and eventually they knocked us into shape,
and we were able, I think, to march reasonably well.
Before we leave Atbridge, there's a couple of other recollections popped up, and I'm not really sure whether I should include them, because things have got to be so politically correct in this year 2021.
But way back in 1940, I think I should really tell it like it was, and in no way dress it up, but we were all lined up for ATT inoculation, anti-tetanus and typhoid.
So there stood two men in white coats, I presume one was a doctor, I don't know, and on this high table were three kidney-shaped white enamel dishes with a blue rim around the top.
They were filled with methylated spirits, and there were two rather large needles, the actual needle of which was not like the fine one that there is nowadays, it was really like a very fine nail, really.
Anyway, there were hundreds of blokes lined up, there were two people, you came along, got it jabbed into your arm, and then that particular needle was thrown into the dish of mass where the other man rinsed it out and refilled it, and in sequence.
So those two needles really injected hundreds of men. That was the ATT inoculation.
And then one day we were all marched up to this large room and all seated down in front of a screen, cinema fashion, and we were shown a film about venereal disease.
Now, looking at ages 18 to 25ish, the likes of me would never have had any sexual education at all, either school, college, home, anywhere.
So this film showed the graphic detail, the horrors that had gone over here, and in the end it showed this chubby, rather like a violent, epileptic fit, who was in the advanced stages of her life.
In the stages of syphilatic locomotor attack here.
But at least this had served the purpose of sex for quite a while, but at least it had taught most of us something of which we had precious little knowledge before.
And then to round this off, the real classic was the FFI parade. Now, I've no idea what an FFI parade was, but we soon found out you stood in a long line in order to drop your trousers and roll up your shirt and expose your genitals.
I thought, hmm, then we realized we were free from infection inspection. Wonderful to lady doctor, but then there weren't many lady doctors in those days, and if it had been the sight of almost hundreds of willies, it would have given us a nervous breakdown.
But anyway, along comes this doctor, I presume, medical officer, and he's carrying like a musical conductor's baton.
And so, anyhow again, he sticks it under someone's willy and makes a bit of a close examination and sees it well done.
So that was the point at which I think I should end my description of Oxbridge and then move on to the next posting, which was Padgate.

But be that as it may, I only stayed at Tuxford for something like a month or so, and now I get posted in October 40 to the RAF Signal School at Cranwell in Lincolnshire.
Now Cranwell in Lincolnshire was the RAF training college, and I learned another aspect of radio operating which did interest me very much, and that was called VHF-DF, very high frequency direction finding.
And it was a means of radio communication which enabled us to establish the position for our own aircraft, radar being very much in its infancy at that stage.
So fighter command in particular relied on VHF-DF, which consisted of three units, something like 40 or so miles apart, from which you drew a line on a bearing taken on their equipment.
And formed what was known as a cocked hat, and in that cocked hat was the position of our own aircraft.
Radio transmission on VHF at ground levels was optical, but air to ground and ground to air was very clear reception.
And sitting, listening out, which we had to do for very long periods at a time, was just listening to a quiet sort of motion, like a pshhhhhh.
And the equipment was set up in wooden towers, and the beauty of all this was those towers were generally well away from any air force establishment.
It was a little unit on its own, and most times the RAF personnel operating it were in civilian pilots.
So to be away from RAF military discipline and operating in one of these units appealed to me very much.
So I set my stall out for that at Cranwell, and over a period of, let me see, something like a month or six weeks, qualified as a VHF-DF operator.
I was then sent to a station in Curtin and Lindsay in Lincolnshire. That was in November 1940.
